elements.content: We report the selective removal of perchlorate from water by a cationic coordination polymer in the highest observed capacity and rate to date. Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[CH3CO2 –]·6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) is easily synthesized in water under ambient conditions (60 min with 99.1% yield). The material releases its environmentally benign acetate anions upon perchlorate uptake to 99.9% mol/mol completion in Millipore water. Actual contaminated industrial water from an underground plume (53 ppm initial perchlorate concentration) was treated to 96% mol/mol in 60 min. The uptake capacity is near-record high at 310 mg/g and is 94% complete within 30 min. Perchlorate exchange was also conducted at 1–30 ppm perchlorate typical of underground contaminated source sites, with up to 99.7% mol/mol completion.
elements.clean_text: We report the selective removal of perchlorate from water by a cationic coordination polymer in the highest observed capacity and rate to date. Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][CH3CO2 -]⋅6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) is easily synthesized in water under ambient conditions (60 min with 99.1% yield). The material releases its environmentally benign acetate anions upon perchlorate uptake to 99.9% mol/mol completion in Millipore water. Actual contaminated industrial water from an underground plume (53 ppm initial perchlorate concentration) was treated to 96% mol/mol in 60 min. The uptake capacity is near-record high at 310 mg/g and is 94% complete within 30 min. Perchlorate exchange was also conducted at 1-30 ppm perchlorate typical of underground contaminated source sites, with up to 99.7% mol/mol completion.

elements.content: Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[CH3CO2 −]·6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) selectively removes perchlorate from water in the highest observed capacity and rate to date while releasing environmentally benign acetate. A new “green” synthesis has been discovered, thereby increasing the viability of this material for environmental remediation.
elements.clean_text: Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][CH3CO2 -]⋅6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) selectively removes perchlorate from water in the highest observed capacity and rate to date while releasing environmentally benign acetate. A new "green" synthesis has been discovered, thereby increasing the viability of this material for environmental remediation.

elements.content: Development of materials to trap toxic oxo-anions from water has expanded in the past decade due to increased need for environmental remediation of pollutants. Perchlorate is still the only oxidant used in rockets and is often present in products such as flares and fireworks. If introduced into the human body, perchlorate can block iodine uptake by the thyroid gland. This blockage can lead to hypothyroidism, negatively affecting metabolic processes in adults and possibly causing improper neural development in children. Currently, the established material for ion trapping is ion exchange resin. The uptake is relatively slow compared to other materials, with limited capacity and reversibility. The perchlorate exchange capacity is only ∼0.6 mequiv/g, and the standard brine regeneration method decreases capacity but moreover is too costly due to its generated waste.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Development of materials to trap toxic oxo-anions from water has expanded in the past decade due to increased need for environmental remediation of pollutants. Perchlorate is still the only oxidant used in rockets and is often present in products such as flares and fireworks. If introduced into the human body, perchlorate can block iodine uptake by the thyroid gland. This blockage can lead to hypothyroidism, negatively affecting metabolic processes in adults and possibly causing improper neural development in children. Currently, the established material for ion trapping is ion exchange resin. The uptake is relatively slow compared to other materials, with limited capacity and reversibility. The perchlorate exchange capacity is only ~0.6 mequiv/g, and the standard brine regeneration method decreases capacity but moreover is too costly due to its generated waste.

elements.content: [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[X–] coordination polymer crystal structures (X– = NO3 –, ClO4 –, BF4 –, –O2C-R-CO2 –, –O3S-R-SO3 –, CrO4 2–, MnO4 –, or ReO4 –) have been studied by our group and others for their potential use as ion exchangers. Two of these structures, silver bipyridine nitrate (SBN, [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[NO3 –]) and SLUG-21 ([Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[−O3SCH2CH2SO3 –]·4H2O), show excellent uptake and preference for toxic anions over potential competitors commonly found in water such as NO3 –, CO3 2–/HCO3 –, and SO4 2–. To date, SBN has been our most promising material for removal of ClO4 – from water. With the very fast and effective removal of ppm level ClO4 –, we are currently studying actual underground contaminated water from the Aerojet Rocketdyne site.
elements.clean_text: [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][X-] coordination polymer crystal structures (X- = NO3 -, ClO4 -, BF4 -, -O2C-R-CO2 -, -O3S-R-SO3 -, CrO4 2-, MnO4 -, or ReO4 -) have been studied by our group and others for their potential use as ion exchangers. Two of these structures, silver bipyridine nitrate (SBN, [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][NO3 -]) and SLUG-21 ([Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][-O3SCH2CH2SO3 -]⋅4H2O), show excellent uptake and preference for toxic anions over potential competitors commonly found in water such as NO3 -, CO3 2-/HCO3 -, and SO4 2-. To date, SBN has been our most promising material for removal of ClO4 - from water. With the very fast and effective removal of ppm level ClO4 -, we are currently studying actual underground contaminated water from the Aerojet Rocketdyne site.

elements.content: Although the above-mentioned materials demonstrate exceptional performance, they exchange for an undesirable anion. Ethanedisulfonate is an expensive reagent and toxic. Nitrate is an EPA pollutant, albeit with a much higher maximum concentration limit (MCL) of 10 ppm level compared to 6 ppb for perchlorate. In 2000, Sampanthar et al. reported silver bipyridine acetate (SBA, [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[CH3CO2 –]·6H2O) when studying the effect of the counteranion of silver-triphenylphosphine coordination polymers. The structure was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), but no properties were reported. Additionally, the synthesis route was slow evaporation of the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) acetonitrile and methanol and gave only a 34% yield. Rapid, high yield synthesis using aqueous “green chemistry” and release of acetate instead of nitrate or ethanedisulfonate would be an exciting move forward for the environmental remediation of toxic oxo-anions.
elements.clean_text: Although the above-mentioned materials demonstrate exceptional performance, they exchange for an undesirable anion. Ethanedisulfonate is an expensive reagent and toxic. Nitrate is an EPA pollutant, albeit with a much higher maximum concentration limit (MCL) of 10 ppm level compared to 6 ppb for perchlorate. In 2000, Sampanthar et al. reported silver bipyridine acetate (SBA, [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][CH3CO2 -]⋅6H2O) when studying the effect of the counteranion of silver-triphenylphosphine coordination polymers. The structure was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), but no properties were reported. Additionally, the synthesis route was slow evaporation of the volatile organic compounds (VOCs) acetonitrile and methanol and gave only a 34% yield. Rapid, high yield synthesis using aqueous "green chemistry" and release of acetate instead of nitrate or ethanedisulfonate would be an exciting move forward for the environmental remediation of toxic oxo-anions.

elements.content: Here, we report the first room temperature, aqueous synthesis of SBA in 1 h with a 99.1% yield, as well as a hydrothermal synthesis of SBA crystals in 3 days with a 62.3% yield. We additionally show that this material has potential as a water remediation tool with incredibly fast uptake of perchlorate in near record-high capacity. The successful exchange of an environmentally benign anion such as acetate for toxic perchlorate is an exciting step forward in the development of these types of materials as ion exchangers.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the first room temperature, aqueous synthesis of SBA in 1 h with a 99.1% yield, as well as a hydrothermal synthesis of SBA crystals in 3 days with a 62.3% yield. We additionally show that this material has potential as a water remediation tool with incredibly fast uptake of perchlorate in near record-high capacity. The successful exchange of an environmentally benign anion such as acetate for toxic perchlorate is an exciting step forward in the development of these types of materials as ion exchangers.

elements.content: Silver acetate (AgCH3CO2, Fisher Chemical, 98%) and 4,4′-bipyridine [(NC5H4)2, Acros Organics, 98%] were used as-received for the synthesis. Sodium perchlorate monohydrate (NaClO4·H2O, Fluka Analytical, 98%) was used as-purchased for the anion exchange reactions. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, Fisher Chemical, 97%) and sulfuric acid (H2SO4, Fisher Chemical, 50%) were used as-purchased for pH dependence experiments. Purolite A532E exchange resin was obtained from Aerojet Rocketdyne and was used as-received for anion exchange experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents

Silver acetate (AgCH3CO2, Fisher Chemical, 98%) and 4,4'-bipyridine [(NC5H4)2, Acros Organics, 98%] were used as-received for the synthesis. Sodium perchlorate monohydrate (NaClO4⋅H2O, Fluka Analytical, 98%) was used as-purchased for the anion exchange reactions. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, Fisher Chemical, 97%) and sulfuric acid (H2SO4, Fisher Chemical, 50%) were used as-purchased for pH dependence experiments. Purolite A532E exchange resin was obtained from Aerojet Rocketdyne and was used as-received for anion exchange experiments.

elements.content: A microcrystalline powder with a blade morphology approximately 1.5 × 0.08 μm2 in size (Figure S1) was synthesized at room temperature. In a typical synthesis, silver acetate (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol) was combined with 4,4′-bipyridine (0.10 g, 0.64 mmol) and 10 mL of Millipore water and gently stirred in a sealed beaker for 1 h. The powder was then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.19 g, 99.1% based on silver acetate). Colorless plate crystals approximately 50 × 50 μm2 in size (Figure S2) were synthesized hydrothermally. In a typical synthesis, the same ratios as above were used and gently stirred for 10 min. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon liner and placed in a 150 °C oven under autogenous pressure over 3 days with slow cooling (ramp rate 99 °C/min; soak time 72 h; cooling rate 0.1 °C/min). The resulting crystals were then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.12 g, 63.2% based on silver acetate).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

A microcrystalline powder with a blade morphology approximately 1.5 × 0.08 μm2 in size (Figure S1) was synthesized at room temperature. In a typical synthesis, silver acetate (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol) was combined with 4,4'-bipyridine (0.10 g, 0.64 mmol) and 10 mL of Millipore water and gently stirred in a sealed beaker for 1 h. The powder was then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.19 g, 99.1% based on silver acetate). Colorless plate crystals approximately 50 × 50 μm2 in size (Figure S2) were synthesized hydrothermally. In a typical synthesis, the same ratios as above were used and gently stirred for 10 min. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon liner and placed in a 150 °C oven under autogenous pressure over 3 days with slow cooling (ramp rate 99 °C/min; soak time 72 h; cooling rate 0.1 °C/min). The resulting crystals were then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.12 g, 63.2% based on silver acetate).

elements.content: Batch experiments for anion exchange were conducted at ambient pressure and temperature. For general anion exchange and loading capacity, 43.5 mg (0.31 mmol, 1 equiv) of perchlorate sodium salt was added to 50 mL of Millipore water in a 100 mL beaker and allowed to dissolve. After dissolution, a 2 mL zero-time point aliquot was taken from the solution. 100 mg (0.31 mmol, 1 equiv) of SBA was then added, the beaker was sealed, and the solution was stirred gently for 48 h, at which point a final aliquot was taken. For kinetics experiments in Millipore water, separate batch experiments were performed so the most accurate data could be obtained with respect to time (see the Supporting Information). For pH studies, solutions of Millipore water with pH levels of 4, 7, and 9 were prepared using sulfuric acid and sodium hydroxide to adjust the pH. 12.6 mg (0.09 mmol, 1 equiv) of perchlorate was added to 50 mL of Millipore water in a 100 mL beaker, and a 2 mL zero-time point aliquot was taken after dissolution. 29.1 mg (0.09 mmol, 1 equiv) of SBA was then added to the solution, a timer was started, the beaker was sealed, and the solution was stirred gently for the allotted amount of time. For the contaminated groundwater, 30.3 mg (0.09 mmol) of SBA was added directly to 50 mL of the groundwater, and the procedures outlined above were followed. The groundwater was pumped from a contaminated underground plume and provided by one of the coauthors (P.B.K.). For both Millipore and industrial water, the final solution was vacuum filtered and the product was collected and analyzed via PXRD. The extent of exchange of ClO4 – was analyzed by ion chromatography (IC).
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange Experiments

Batch experiments for anion exchange were conducted at ambient pressure and temperature. For general anion exchange and loading capacity, 43.5 mg (0.31 mmol, 1 equiv) of perchlorate sodium salt was added to 50 mL of Millipore water in a 100 mL beaker and allowed to dissolve. After dissolution, a 2 mL zero-time point aliquot was taken from the solution. 100 mg (0.31 mmol, 1 equiv) of SBA was then added, the beaker was sealed, and the solution was stirred gently for 48 h, at which point a final aliquot was taken. For kinetics experiments in Millipore water, separate batch experiments were performed so the most accurate data could be obtained with respect to time (see the Supporting Information). For pH studies, solutions of Millipore water with pH levels of 4, 7, and 9 were prepared using sulfuric acid and sodium hydroxide to adjust the pH. 12.6 mg (0.09 mmol, 1 equiv) of perchlorate was added to 50 mL of Millipore water in a 100 mL beaker, and a 2 mL zero-time point aliquot was taken after dissolution. 29.1 mg (0.09 mmol, 1 equiv) of SBA was then added to the solution, a timer was started, the beaker was sealed, and the solution was stirred gently for the allotted amount of time. For the contaminated groundwater, 30.3 mg (0.09 mmol) of SBA was added directly to 50 mL of the groundwater, and the procedures outlined above were followed. The groundwater was pumped from a contaminated underground plume and provided by one of the coauthors (P.B.K.). For both Millipore and industrial water, the final solution was vacuum filtered and the product was collected and analyzed via PXRD. The extent of exchange of ClO4 - was analyzed by ion chromatography (IC).

elements.content: Conditions were the same as above. 50 mL solutions of 1, 5, 10, 15, and 30 ppm of ClO4 – in Millipore water were prepared and an initial 2 mL aliquot was taken. 15 mg (0.046 mmol) of SBA was then added. The solutions were stirred gently for 2 days, at which point a final 2 mL aliquot was taken.
elements.clean_text:
Low ppm Anion Exchange

Conditions were the same as above. 50 mL solutions of 1, 5, 10, 15, and 30 ppm of ClO4 - in Millipore water were prepared and an initial 2 mL aliquot was taken. 15 mg (0.046 mmol) of SBA was then added. The solutions were stirred gently for 2 days, at which point a final 2 mL aliquot was taken.

elements.content: SCXRD was collected on a Bruker APEX-II diffractometer using a combination of ω- and φ-scans of 0.5°. Data were corrected for absorption and polarization effects and analyzed for space group determination. The structure was solved by dual-space methods and expanded routinely. The model was refined by full-matrix least-squares analysis of F 2 against all reflections. PXRD was measured on a Rigaku Americas Miniflex Plus diffractometer, scanning from 2° to 50° (2θ) at a rate of 2°·min–1 with a 0.04° step size under Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). IC analysis was performed to assess perchlorate concentration using a Dionex ICS-3000 with an IonPac AS20 column and a detection limit of 3 μg/L (ppb). A standard curve for perchlorate was prepared for all IC experiments to quantify the concentration of the samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected with an FEI Quanta 3D Dualbeam microscope. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) measurements were taken on a PerkinElmer Optima 4300DV, run in radial mode using yttrium as an internal standard for the solubility experiments. A standard curve for silver­(I) was prepared to quantify the amount of free silver in the samples.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

SCXRD was collected on a Bruker APEX-II diffractometer using a combination of ω- and φ-scans of 0.5°. Data were corrected for absorption and polarization effects and analyzed for space group determination. The structure was solved by dual-space methods and expanded routinely. The model was refined by full-matrix least-squares analysis of F 2 against all reflections. PXRD was measured on a Rigaku Americas Miniflex Plus diffractometer, scanning from 2° to 50° (2θ) at a rate of 2°⋅min-1 with a 0.04° step size under Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). IC analysis was performed to assess perchlorate concentration using a Dionex ICS-3000 with an IonPac AS20 column and a detection limit of 3 μg/L (ppb). A standard curve for perchlorate was prepared for all IC experiments to quantify the concentration of the samples. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected with an FEI Quanta 3D Dualbeam microscope. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) measurements were taken on a PerkinElmer Optima 4300DV, run in radial mode using yttrium as an internal standard for the solubility experiments. A standard curve for silver(I) was prepared to quantify the amount of free silver in the samples.

elements.content: A white microcrystalline powder was synthesized under aqueous room temperature (RT) conditions in 60 min. Hydrothermal synthesis at 130 and 150 °C also yielded pure-phase SBA, although single crystals were not obtained at 130 °C. Hydrothermal synthesis at 175 and 200 °C both yielded as-yet unknown patterns (Figure S3). Previously, SBA was synthesized in acetonitrile and methanol by evaporation over 2 days, yielding block crystals and a 35% yield. Our 1 h RT synthesis is much faster, has far higher yield of 99.1%, and does not require VOCs.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

A white microcrystalline powder was synthesized under aqueous room temperature (RT) conditions in 60 min. Hydrothermal synthesis at 130 and 150 °C also yielded pure-phase SBA, although single crystals were not obtained at 130 °C. Hydrothermal synthesis at 175 and 200 °C both yielded as-yet unknown patterns (Figure S3). Previously, SBA was synthesized in acetonitrile and methanol by evaporation over 2 days, yielding block crystals and a 35% yield. Our 1 h RT synthesis is much faster, has far higher yield of 99.1%, and does not require VOCs.

elements.content: Given our alternate synthesis route, we have also solved the structure of our crystals by SCXRD. There are two silver centers, two acetate anions, two 4,4′-bipyridine linkers, and six water molecules of crystallization in the asymmetric unit of the primitive, centrosymmetric, monoclinc space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit is shown in . Most of the [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[X–] structures have the guest anions sandwiched between layers of π-stacked polymeric chains, where the latter contain Ag+ chelated by the nitrogens of two neutral 4,4′-bipyridine units. Here, we again see a similar layout, except four silver atoms are co-linear and arranged into two dimers [3.1347(8) Å], slightly reducing the amount of π-stacking but leading to greater covalent connectivity within the layer. These sheets are further stabilized by π-stacking of the bipyridine rings [3.425(8)–3.699(8) Å]. The acetates charge-balance the polymers and μ-2 bridge two Ag centers of adjacent polymers (, , S4). The Ag(1) coordinated by the nitrogens of two 4,4′-bipyridine units and one oxygen from two separate CH3CO2 – units define a distorted square planar geometry. The interstitial water molecules occupy the interlayer space between the silver complex chains and form an extensive hydrogen-bonded network [1.9271(8)–2.0970(8) Å]. Hydrophobic pockets exist in the region of the acetate methyl group and bipyridine rings (Figure S4). One of the pyridine moieties has been modeled with positional disorder over two sites; the disorder is a rocking of the pyridine anchored at the nitrogen and para-carbon atom. There is a second pyridine moiety that has elongated displacement parameters and is tending toward some disorder but was not further modeled as such.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

Given our alternate synthesis route, we have also solved the structure of our crystals by SCXRD. There are two silver centers, two acetate anions, two 4,4'-bipyridine linkers, and six water molecules of crystallization in the asymmetric unit of the primitive, centrosymmetric, monoclinc space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit is shown in . Most of the [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][X-] structures have the guest anions sandwiched between layers of π-stacked polymeric chains, where the latter contain Ag+ chelated by the nitrogens of two neutral 4,4'-bipyridine units. Here, we again see a similar layout, except four silver atoms are co-linear and arranged into two dimers [3.1347(8) Å], slightly reducing the amount of π-stacking but leading to greater covalent connectivity within the layer. These sheets are further stabilized by π-stacking of the bipyridine rings [3.425(8)-3.699(8) Å]. The acetates charge-balance the polymers and μ-2 bridge two Ag centers of adjacent polymers (, , S4). The Ag(1) coordinated by the nitrogens of two 4,4'-bipyridine units and one oxygen from two separate CH3CO2 - units define a distorted square planar geometry. The interstitial water molecules occupy the interlayer space between the silver complex chains and form an extensive hydrogen-bonded network [1.9271(8)-2.0970(8) Å]. Hydrophobic pockets exist in the region of the acetate methyl group and bipyridine rings (Figure S4). One of the pyridine moieties has been modeled with positional disorder over two sites; the disorder is a rocking of the pyridine anchored at the nitrogen and para-carbon atom. There is a second pyridine moiety that has elongated displacement parameters and is tending toward some disorder but was not further modeled as such.

elements.content: Crystal data for C24H34Ag2N4O10: M r = 754.29; monoclinic; space group P21/c; a = 11.464(3) Å; b = 18.299(5) Å; c = 14.010(4) Å; α = 90°; β = 102.275(4)°; γ = 90°; V = 2871.8(13) Å3; Z = 4; T = 120(2) K; λ­(Mo–Kα) = 0.71073 Å; μ­(Mo–Kα) = 1.424 mm–1; d calc = 1.745 g·cm–3; 66 324 reflections collected; 7211 unique (R int = 0.0340); giving R1 = 0.0237, wR2 = 0.0572 for 6102 data with [I > 2σ­(I)] and R1 = 0.0326, wR2 = 0.0610 for all 7211 data. Residual electron density (e–·Å–3) max/min: 0.427/–0.505.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal data for C24H34Ag2N4O10: M r = 754.29; monoclinic; space group P21/c; a = 11.464(3) Å; b = 18.299(5) Å; c = 14.010(4) Å; α = 90°; β = 102.275(4)°; γ = 90°; V = 2871.8(13) Å3; Z = 4; T = 120(2) K; λ(Mo-Kα) = 0.71073 Å; μ(Mo-Kα) = 1.424 mm-1; d calc = 1.745 g⋅cm-3; 66324 reflections collected; 7211 unique (R int = 0.0340); giving R1 = 0.0237, wR2 = 0.0572 for 6102 data with [I > 2σ(I)] and R1 = 0.0326, wR2 = 0.0610 for all 7211 data. Residual electron density (e-⋅Å-3) max/min: 0.427/-0.505.

elements.content: Adjacent linear chains seen end-on in this a-projection are bridged vertically by Ag–Ag pairs and acetate molecules.
elements.clean_text: 2  Adjacent linear chains seen end-on in this a-projection are bridged vertically by Ag-Ag pairs and acetate molecules.

elements.content: An alternate view of SBA with the acetates and occluded waters omitted for clarity. Left: one layer of π-stacked [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+] polymers where two adjacent silver dimers are co-linear. Right: [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+] layers viewed end-on down the crystallographic a-axis. For both views, one of the dimerized polymers is highlighted in red.
elements.clean_text: 3  An alternate view of SBA with the acetates and occluded waters omitted for clarity. Left: one layer of π-stacked [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+] polymers where two adjacent silver dimers are co-linear. Right: [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+] layers viewed end-on down the crystallographic a-axis. For both views, one of the dimerized polymers is highlighted in red.

elements.content: Considering the outstanding ion exchange capabilities found in other silver bipyridine structures, the kinetics and loading capacity of perchlorate by SBA were examined. The exchanges were followed by both IC and PXRD. The kinetics showed that 94% of perchlorate uptake by SBA takes place in the first 30 min (, , S5), transforming SBA to silver bipyridine perchlorate (SBP, [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[ClO4 –]). Graphical analysis suggests the kinetics follows a second-order reaction mechanism with k = 0.0845(1) M–1 s–1 (Figure S6). In comparison to the previously reported materials (), SBA shows superior kinetics for perchlorate uptake over SBN, Amberlite IRA-400, and calcined hydrotalcite.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange

Considering the outstanding ion exchange capabilities found in other silver bipyridine structures, the kinetics and loading capacity of perchlorate by SBA were examined. The exchanges were followed by both IC and PXRD. The kinetics showed that 94% of perchlorate uptake by SBA takes place in the first 30 min (, , S5), transforming SBA to silver bipyridine perchlorate (SBP, [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][ClO4 -]). Graphical analysis suggests the kinetics follows a second-order reaction mechanism with k = 0.0845(1) M-1 s-1 (Figure S6). In comparison to the previously reported materials (), SBA shows superior kinetics for perchlorate uptake over SBN, Amberlite IRA-400, and calcined hydrotalcite.

elements.content: Left: perchlorate loading capacity versus time. Right: perchlorate removal from water in ppm versus time.
elements.clean_text: 4  Left: perchlorate loading capacity versus time. Right: perchlorate removal from water in ppm versus time.

elements.content: SBA compared with SBN, Amberlite IRA-400 exchange resin, and hydrotalcite shows the decrease of perchlorate in mM ClO4 – per gram of material. All data other than that of SBA were previously published by our group.
elements.clean_text: 5  SBA compared with SBN, Amberlite IRA-400 exchange resin, and hydrotalcite shows the decrease of perchlorate in mM ClO4 - per gram of material. All data other than that of SBA were previously published by our group.

elements.content: Given the above record performance of SBA using equimolar perchlorate, ClO4 – concentrations typical of underground contaminated water plumes were also investigated to determine the potential application of this material. Perchlorate removal with SBA powder was tested for 30, 15, 10, 5, and 1 ppm solutions over a period of 2 days. 15 mg of SBA exchanged for perchlorate to 95.7–99.7% completion (). Despite the low concentration, the uptake clearly demonstrates the potential utility of this material over a far shorter time frame than the several weeks needed by single-use exchange resins currently used industrially with single-use exchange resins.
elements.clean_text:
Perchlorate Exchange at ppm Level

Given the above record performance of SBA using equimolar perchlorate, ClO4 - concentrations typical of underground contaminated water plumes were also investigated to determine the potential application of this material. Perchlorate removal with SBA powder was tested for 30, 15, 10, 5, and 1 ppm solutions over a period of 2 days. 15 mg of SBA exchanged for perchlorate to 95.7-99.7% completion (). Despite the low concentration, the uptake clearly demonstrates the potential utility of this material over a far shorter time frame than the several weeks needed by single-use exchange resins currently used industrially with single-use exchange resins.

The performance of SBA in actual contaminated groundwater was also investigated to ensure that competing ions would not present a significant issue. Through our collaboration with one of the coauthors (P.B.K.), we obtained samples of contaminated groundwater with a perchlorate concentration of ca. 53 ppm. The water also contained chloride (13 ppm), sulfate (11 ppm), nitrate (1.5 ppm), orthophosphate (0.079 ppm), and trichloroethene (3 ppm) after analysis with their third party testing company. Initial tests show that, after 30 min, SBA powder removed 92.5% of perchlorate, and up to 95.9% after 1 h ().
elements.clean_text:
Perchlorate Removal from Contaminated Underground Water

The performance of SBA in actual contaminated groundwater was also investigated to ensure that competing ions would not present a significant issue. Through our collaboration with one of the coauthors (P.B.K.), we obtained samples of contaminated groundwater with a perchlorate concentration of ca. 53 ppm. The water also contained chloride (13 ppm), sulfate (11 ppm), nitrate (1.5 ppm), orthophosphate (0.079 ppm), and trichloroethene (3 ppm) after analysis with their third party testing company. Initial tests show that, after 30 min, SBA powder removed 92.5% of perchlorate, and up to 95.9% after 1 h ().

elements.content: Removal of perchlorate versus time for the contaminated groundwater.
elements.clean_text: 6  Removal of perchlorate versus time for the contaminated groundwater.

elements.content: SBA powder was used in all kinetics exchanges (vide supra), so its surface area was greater than that of a resin and therefore would be expected to have more rapid perchlorate uptake. Our collaborator currently uses Purolite A532E exchange resin microparticles of approximately 50 μm in diameter. Our single crystals of SBA are closer in size to the Purolite A532E resin at approximately 50 × 50 μm2. We compared the exchange kinetics of the Purolite to the SBA single crystals using a gentle top-stirrer to promote continuous exchange while limiting any mechanical breakdown of the SBA crystals. After 30 min, the Purolite had a perchlorate uptake of 15.5% and, after 120 min, an uptake of 49.6%. The values are compared to 50.5% and 77.2%, respectively, using SBA crystals (Figure S7). Although the uptake of the SBA crystals versus the SBA powder is expectedly slower, it is still far more rapid than that of the currently used Purolite.
elements.clean_text: SBA powder was used in all kinetics exchanges (vide supra), so its surface area was greater than that of a resin and therefore would be expected to have more rapid perchlorate uptake. Our collaborator currently uses Purolite A532E exchange resin microparticles of approximately 50 μm in diameter. Our single crystals of SBA are closer in size to the Purolite A532E resin at approximately 50 × 50 μm2. We compared the exchange kinetics of the Purolite to the SBA single crystals using a gentle top-stirrer to promote continuous exchange while limiting any mechanical breakdown of the SBA crystals. After 30 min, the Purolite had a perchlorate uptake of 15.5% and, after 120 min, an uptake of 49.6%. The values are compared to 50.5% and 77.2%, respectively, using SBA crystals (Figure S7). Although the uptake of the SBA crystals versus the SBA powder is expectedly slower, it is still far more rapid than that of the currently used Purolite.

elements.content: Initial solubility studies of SBA by ICP-OES indicate that it is more soluble in water than SBP, possibly due to its lower stability and/or the lower hydration energy of the perchlorate (ΔG hydr°: −214 kJ/mol) as compared to acetate (ΔG hydr°: −373 kJ/mol). In fact, the greater stability of SBP is highly beneficial for the trapping of the toxic perchlorate while releasing the environmentally benign acetate. It poses a challenge, however, for regeneration from SBP to SBA. In our previously published research, it was determined that, after exchange, SBP could be regenerated back to SBN over indefinite cycles. We therefore believe SBA could be an excellent “first-pass” material for perchlorate removal from industrial waters due to its fast kinetics, high loading capacity, and exchange for an environmentally benign anion.
elements.clean_text:
Solubility

Initial solubility studies of SBA by ICP-OES indicate that it is more soluble in water than SBP, possibly due to its lower stability and/or the lower hydration energy of the perchlorate (ΔG hydr°: -214 kJ/mol) as compared to acetate (ΔG hydr°: -373 kJ/mol). In fact, the greater stability of SBP is highly beneficial for the trapping of the toxic perchlorate while releasing the environmentally benign acetate. It poses a challenge, however, for regeneration from SBP to SBA. In our previously published research, it was determined that, after exchange, SBP could be regenerated back to SBN over indefinite cycles. We therefore believe SBA could be an excellent "first-pass" material for perchlorate removal from industrial waters due to its fast kinetics, high loading capacity, and exchange for an environmentally benign anion.

elements.content: Industrial waters often have varying pH levels. Therefore, the extent of exchange over a range of pH levels was examined (). At a pH as low as 4, the SBA is still able to achieve 92% uptake of perchlorate and retain relatively good crystallinity as can be seen by PXRD. Since acetate is the conjugate base of a weak acid, in more acidic conditions acetate released may be immediately protonated, making it unavailable for potential reformation of SBA. This would result in an equilibrium push toward perchlorate uptake and formation of SBP. At these more acidic pH levels, however, some breakdown of the material would be expected, thus leading to less than 99.9% uptake of perchlorate seen in the previously discussed exchanges. SBA does not perform as well in basic conditions, possibly due to competition by unprotonated acetate. It is more likely, however, that the material is not as stable in basic conditions. Partial breakdown as reflected in the reduced crystallinity by PXRD for pH 9 and 10 ( inset) would decrease the perchlorate uptake.
elements.clean_text:
pH Studies

Industrial waters often have varying pH levels. Therefore, the extent of exchange over a range of pH levels was examined (). At a pH as low as 4, the SBA is still able to achieve 92% uptake of perchlorate and retain relatively good crystallinity as can be seen by PXRD. Since acetate is the conjugate base of a weak acid, in more acidic conditions acetate released may be immediately protonated, making it unavailable for potential reformation of SBA. This would result in an equilibrium push toward perchlorate uptake and formation of SBP. At these more acidic pH levels, however, some breakdown of the material would be expected, thus leading to less than 99.9% uptake of perchlorate seen in the previously discussed exchanges. SBA does not perform as well in basic conditions, possibly due to competition by unprotonated acetate. It is more likely, however, that the material is not as stable in basic conditions. Partial breakdown as reflected in the reduced crystallinity by PXRD for pH 9 and 10 ( inset) would decrease the perchlorate uptake.

elements.content: Removal of perchlorate from solutions of varying pH levels. Inset: corresponding PXRD measurements; the SBP theoretical pattern is displayed in black with lower intensity peaks (25% of max threshold) omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 7  Removal of perchlorate from solutions of varying pH levels. Inset: corresponding PXRD measurements; the SBP theoretical pattern is displayed in black with lower intensity peaks (25% of max threshold) omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In summary, we have determined that SBA is an extremely fast and effective material for removing ClO4 – from water. It can be synthesized in 60 min in air with no need for organic solvents. It has high loading capacity and record speed, while releasing an environmentally benign anion. In fact, acetate can be utilized by bacteria to facilitate the reduction of perchlorate and nitrate in water, potentially providing further benefit. The material has also shown to be effective at removing perchlorate from actual contaminated industrial water containing other common ions in addition to perchlorate.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have determined that SBA is an extremely fast and effective material for removing ClO4 - from water. It can be synthesized in 60 min in air with no need for organic solvents. It has high loading capacity and record speed, while releasing an environmentally benign anion. In fact, acetate can be utilized by bacteria to facilitate the reduction of perchlorate and nitrate in water, potentially providing further benefit. The material has also shown to be effective at removing perchlorate from actual contaminated industrial water containing other common ions in addition to perchlorate.

cln_elements.content: A microcrystalline powder with a blade morphology approximately 1.5 × 0.08 μm2 in size (Figure S1) was synthesized at room temperature. In a typical synthesis, silver acetate (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol) was combined with 4,4′-bipyridine (0.10 g, 0.64 mmol) and 10 mL of Millipore water and gently stirred in a sealed beaker for 1 h. The powder was then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.19 g, 99.1% based on silver acetate). Colorless plate crystals approximately 50 × 50 μm2 in size (Figure S2) were synthesized hydrothermally. In a typical synthesis, the same ratios as above were used and gently stirred for 10 min. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon liner and placed in a 150 °C oven under autogenous pressure over 3 days with slow cooling (ramp rate 99 °C/min; soak time 72 h; cooling rate 0.1 °C/min). The resulting crystals were then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.12 g, 63.2% based on silver acetate).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

A microcrystalline powder with a blade morphology approximately 1.5 × 0.08 μm2 in size (Figure S1) was synthesized at room temperature. In a typical synthesis, silver acetate (0.10 g, 0.60 mmol) was combined with 4,4'-bipyridine (0.10 g, 0.64 mmol) and 10 mL of Millipore water and gently stirred in a sealed beaker for 1 h. The powder was then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.19 g, 99.1% based on silver acetate). Colorless plate crystals approximately 50 × 50 μm2 in size (Figure S2) were synthesized hydrothermally. In a typical synthesis, the same ratios as above were used and gently stirred for 10 min. The mixture was then transferred into a Teflon liner and placed in a 150 °C oven under autogenous pressure over 3 days with slow cooling (ramp rate 99 °C/min; soak time 72 h; cooling rate 0.1 °C/min). The resulting crystals were then collected via vacuum filtration and rinsed with deionized water and acetone (yield: 0.12 g, 63.2% based on silver acetate).

cln_elements.content: We report the selective removal of perchlorate from water by a cationic coordination polymer in the highest observed capacity and rate to date. Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag­(4,4′-bipy)+]­[CH3CO2 –]·6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) is easily synthesized in water under ambient conditions (60 min with 99.1% yield). The material releases its environmentally benign acetate anions upon perchlorate uptake to 99.9% mol/mol completion in Millipore water. Actual contaminated industrial water from an underground plume (53 ppm initial perchlorate concentration) was treated to 96% mol/mol in 60 min. The uptake capacity is near-record high at 310 mg/g and is 94% complete within 30 min. Perchlorate exchange was also conducted at 1–30 ppm perchlorate typical of underground contaminated source sites, with up to 99.7% mol/mol completion.
cln_elements.clean_text: We report the selective removal of perchlorate from water by a cationic coordination polymer in the highest observed capacity and rate to date. Silver bipyridine acetate [Ag(4,4'-bipy)+][CH3CO2 -]⋅6H2O (bipy = bipyridine) is easily synthesized in water under ambient conditions (60 min with 99.1% yield). The material releases its environmentally benign acetate anions upon perchlorate uptake to 99.9% mol/mol completion in Millipore water. Actual contaminated industrial water from an underground plume (53 ppm initial perchlorate concentration) was treated to 96% mol/mol in 60 min. The uptake capacity is near-record high at 310 mg/g and is 94% complete within 30 min. Perchlorate exchange was also conducted at 1-30 ppm perchlorate typical of underground contaminated source sites, with up to 99.7% mol/mol completion.

at 1-30 ppm perchlorate typical of underground contaminated source sites

metadata.title:
Extremely Rapid Uptake of Perchlorate with Release
of an Environmentally Benign
Anion: Silver Bipyridine Acetate
